description: A descriptive term indicating the data collection technique. Examples of valid categories are: CSP for complete soil profile description, MP for mini profile (50-100 cm), SA for soil auger, O for other soil sample.
Geographic latitude on the WGS84 ellipsoid. The values should be rounded to six decimal points. Example: -12.912203 (corresponds to 1 m precision).
Estimated positional accuracy (95% propability error radius) in meters.
Beginning of the reference period to which the soil variables entered in this 14 record refer to. Rounded to a day in ISO 8601 date and time in UTC (GMT) 15 system.
End of the reference period to which the soil variables entered in this record refer to. Rounded to a day in ISO 8601 date and time in UTC (GMT) system.
Organic carbon content in soil, usually estimated using the method of Walkley-Black (Org. matter = Org. C x 1.72).
Soil pH, usually measured in water.
Mass of the soil material divided by the total volume it occupies.
Soil type according to the FAO classification system (taxonomic group).

fullname: USDA's Keys to Soil Taxonomy class order
description: Soil type according to the USDA classification system (order).
units: 1 : Gelisols; 2 : Histosols; 3 : Spodosols; 4 : Andisols; 5 : Oxisols; 6 : Vertisols; 7 : Aridisols; 8 : Ultisols; 9 : Mollisols; 10 : Alfisols; 11 : Inceptisols; 12 : Entisols

description: Hue is the dominant spectral colour (red, yellow, green, blue or violet), value is the lightness or darkness of colour ranging from 1 (dark) to 8 (light), and chroma is the purity or strength of colour ranging from 1 (pale) to 8 (bright).

Hue is the dominant spectral colour (red, yellow, green, blue or violet), value is the lightness or darkness of colour ranging from 1 (dark) to 8 (light), and chroma is the purity or strength of colour ranging from 1 (pale) to 8 (bright).
Weight percentage of particles 50-2 mm size.
Weight percentage of particles 2-50 micro-m size.
Weight percentage of particles <2 micro-m size.
Volume percentage of fragments >2 mm size.
USDA soil texture class estimated by hand.
units: 1 : clay (light); 2 : clay loam; 3 : clay (heavy); 4 : loam; 5 : loamy sand; 6 : sand; 7 : sandy clay; 8 : sandy clay loam; 9 : sandy loam; 10 : silt; 11 : silt loam; 12 : silty clay; 13 : silty clay loam

description: Cation Exchange Capacity expresses the total nutrient fixing capacity of a soil. Soils with low CEC have little resilience and can not build up stores of nutrients.

The salt content of a soil can be roughly estimated from the Electrical Conductivity of the soil (EC, expressed in dS m-1) measured in a saturated soil paste or a more diluted suspension of soil in water. Crops vary considerably in their resistance and response to salt in soils.
Weight percentage of CAC03.

The Percent Base Saturation measures the sum of exchangeable cations (nutrients) Na, Ca, Mg and K as a percentage of the overall exchange capacity of the soil (including the same cations plus H and Al). The value often shows a near linear correlation with pH.
Nitrogen (N) is essential for plant growth. It ranks behind only carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in total quantity needed and is the mineral element most demanded by plants.
Gypsum is a chemical compound (a salt) which occurs occasionally in soils particularly in the driest areas of the globe where it can occur in a flower-like form.
Depth at which an obstacle for roots exists, estimated in cm.
Available water capacity is the amount of water that a soil can store that is available for use by plants.
Geographic longitude on the WGS84 ellipsoid. The values should be rounded to six decimal points. Example: 2.107201 (corresponds to 1 m precision).

fullname: Depth to fixed rock or bedrock
description: Hard bedrock is usually indurated but may be strongly cemented, and excavation difficulty would be very high or higher. Soft bedrock meets the consistence requirements for paralithic contact
Rock outcrops in terms of percentage surface cover for a block of land (100 by 100 m), according to the FAO Guidelines for Soil Profile description.
Upper horizon depth measured in cm from the soil surface.
Lower horizon depth measured in cm from the soil surface.
Observed depth to ground water in cm at the time of soil profile description

fullname: Source ID of the original data set
description: Usually the abbreviated institution name and profile number
